Abortiporus biennis.Description: A beautiful, wide-pored annual polypore with a varied appearance. Its most common form is the rosette form, but it has many different irregular forms, including an upside-down, hemispherical form too.
Abortiporus biennis.Synonyms: Grifola biennis, Heteroporus biennis, Polyporus biennis, Daedalea biennis
Abortiporus biennis.Fruiting Body: Often forms irregular fruit bodies, the below mentioned description describes the regular, rosette form of the species. Cap 5–20 cm across, nearly flat, roundish to rosette-like, turns irregularly lobe with age; nearby fruit bodies often fused together. Its upper, sterile surface is initially white to off-white, then pink to reddish brown; smooth to slightly hairy ( tomentose ). Margin thin and paler than the rest of the upper surface, bruising reddish brown when handled or damaged. Stem 4–7 cm long and 2–3 cm thick, tapering towards the base, often deeply ‘rooting’.
Abortiporus biennis.Pores: Tubes 5–6 mm long, creamy white. Pores 1–3 per mm (sometimes even wider), irregularly angular to daedaleoid , slightly decurrent ; white, staining pink to reddish if damaged.
Abortiporus biennis.Flesh: Dual-layered ( duplex ), 8–10 mm thick. The upper (external) layer is soft and ochraceous, while the core or inner layer is a bit harder (corky) and more cream in colour.
Abortiporus biennis.Habitat: On all kind of hardwood, often on buried roots, more rarely on conifers. Saprotrophic , causes white-rot, most of all in the roots of deciduous trees. Growing solitary or in smaller groups. Its main fruiting season is Late Summer to Autumn, but it can be found during the whole year.
Abortiporus biennis.Possible Confusion: Young, irregular fruit bodies secrete/oozing red droplets. In this form it can be confused with Devil’s Tooth ( Hydnellum peckii ) and/or Mealy Tooth ( Hydnellum ferrugineum ), but both species can be found exclusively in old conifer forests, near Pine or Spruce, also these species have spines (teeth), not wide pores. The regular fruit bodies might be confused with the rarer Zoned Rosette ( Podoscypha multizonata ), pictured, which also prefers hardwoods, especially Oaks, but Zoned Rosette doesn’t have visible pores. If we look it more carefully it more reminds of a pink to red stained Wood Cauliflower ( Sparassis crispa ) than a Blushing Rosette.
Abortiporus biennis.Taste / Smell: Inedible, taste mild, but it has a strange mushroomy smell (some authors describe the smell as somewhat unpleasant).
Abortiporus biennis.Frequency: Occasional and widespread in the UK.
Abortiporus biennis.Spores: Spore print is white. Spores elliptical, colourless ( hyaline ), and thin walled with oil drops.
Abortiporus biennis.Other Facts: It often forms irregular, aberrant fruit bodies. It could be hemispherical with its pores upside-down, but even if it forms its regular, rosette form, the so-called ‘rosecomb mutation’ is rather common. In mycology, the term ‘rosecomb mutation’ is used when any kind of distortions, lumps or malformations occur on the cap and makes visible the gills or the pores. Its epithet (the 2nd part of the scientific name which identifies the species within the genus) – biennis – suggests it is biennial, but it is incorrect, and likely based on the really variable appearance of this species.

Agaricus arvensis.Description: A great mushroom with a rich, strong taste and as it can grow so large and in rings, usually provides quite a feast.
Agaricus arvensis.Cap: 10-16 cm. White, sometimes discoloured grey/brown, can be scaly or smooth. Starting spherical and opening out flat. Can bruise slightly yellow.
Agaricus arvensis.Gills: Crowded and free of the stem. When very young the gills are almost white but quickly turn from pale pink/grey to brown in more mature specimens. On unopened caps, the ring while still joined to the cap, looks like a ‘cog wheel’.
Agaricus arvensis.Stem: 10-16 cm long, 2-3 cm diameter. Smooth and white with a double edged ring, can be finely flocculose toward the base.
Agaricus arvensis.Skirt: Superior. Can start fairly large but usually becomes damaged or shrinks to a ring. Has a double edge.
Agaricus arvensis.Flesh: White, firm and bruising slightly yellow. The flesh has an aniseed smell.
Agaricus arvensis.Habitat: Pasture, meadows, lawns, road verges and parks, often growing in rings.
Agaricus arvensis.Possible Confusion: The Yellow Stainer ( Agaricus xanthodermus ) but this mushroom stains chrome yellow when bruised or cut and smells of Indian ink, hospitals or iodine and is not edible. The Macro Mushroom (Agaricus crocodilinus) looks very similar but has a stouter stem covered in floccules below the skirt and more of a bitter almond aroma although some people smell aniseed only. This wouldn’t be a dangerous mistake, the Macro Mushroom is a great edible Agaric. Can look similar to some of the Amanitas when young and light gilled but the Horse Mushroom does not have the bulbous base or volval sack that Amanitas have.
Agaricus arvensis.Spore Print: Dark purple/brown. Ellipsoid. You should scrape your spores into a small pile to get an accurate spore colour.
Agaricus arvensis.Taste / Smell: Excellent, this is one of our  favourites. The smell of aniseed is a good way to identify this mushroom. Should be cooked before consumption.
Agaricus arvensis.Frequency: Occasional and widespread in most parts of the UK, but can be locally common.
Agaricus arvensis.Other Facts: In March 2025 the IUCN (International Union for Conservation of Nature) added 1000 fungal species to the IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. The IUCN (Global) Conservation Status of Horse Mushroom ( Agaricus arvensis ) is: LC – Least Concern, with stable population. For more information, see on the following link .

Agaricus augustus.Description: A very tasty Agaric but it can accumulate cadmium so best picked from the wild away from urban spaces and busy roads.
Agaricus augustus.Average Cap width (CM): 10-16 but can be found up to 25cm
Agaricus augustus.Cap: Up to 25 cm. Spherical when young becoming convex. Covered in concentric chestnut brown scales on a white to pale yellow background. Can stain yellow on the edges where touched.
Agaricus augustus.Gills: Crowded and free of the stem. Gills starting off white to pink, maturing to dark brown.
Agaricus augustus.Stem: 10-16 cm long, 2-3.5 cm diameter. White to pale cream and smooth above the skirt and covered in small brown scales below.
Agaricus augustus.Flesh: White sometimes with a yellow tinge where cut or bruised.
Agaricus augustus.Habitat: Mixed woodland, particularly under conifers, lawns and roadsides, .
Agaricus augustus.Possible Confusion: The Inky Mushroom ( Agaricus moelleri ), pictured, looks similar but the chemical, unpleasant smell of the flesh of this mushroom should keep you safe. The Prince also looks a little like some of the Lepiotas but these always have white/off white gills not the pale pink to brown gills of the Agaric family. The Freckled Dapperling ( Echinoderma asperum ) looks very similar but has ‘warts’ on the cap instead of  scales and has white gills unlike the Prince’s off white to pink to black gills.
Agaricus augustus.Taste / Smell: Excellent. Mushroomy. The flesh smells of bitter almonds. Should be cooked before consumption.

Agaricus bitorquis.Description: This fungi can grow through dry, compacted soil or even asphalt and seems to prefer growing beside paths and roads hence its common name.
Agaricus bitorquis.Cap: 8-12 cm. White and convex opening out to flat in mature specimens. The cap is often covered in mud and dust.
Agaricus bitorquis.Gills: Crowded, not joined to the stem. Gills off white/grey at first soon turning pink to dark brown.
Agaricus bitorquis.Stem: 6-10cm long, 1.5-2 cm diameter. Robust, white and often tapering at the base.
Agaricus bitorquis.Skirt: Has an inferior, double edged skirt, obvious in this picture, not always so on other Pavement Mushrooms.
Agaricus bitorquis.Flesh: Meaty  white flesh turning slightly pink on cutting.
Agaricus bitorquis.Habitat: Roadsides, path edges, under trees, bare soil, gardens or manure.
Agaricus bitorquis.Possible Confusion: The Yellow Stainer ( Agaricus xanthodermus ), but this mushroom stains chrome yellow when bruised or cut and smells of Indian ink, hospitals or iodine and not edible. Can look similar to some of the Amanitas when young and white gilled.
Agaricus bitorquis.Taste / Smell: Strong and mushroomy. Should be cooked before consumption.
Agaricus bitorquis.Frequency: Occasional but widespread on the British Isles.
Agaricus bitorquis.Other Facts: This seems to be the favourite mushroom of choice for maggots and even mushrooms that have just broken the surface are usually riddled with them. They are great tasting if you can find them maggot free or don’t mind the extra protein! In March 2025 the IUCN (International Union for Conservation of Nature) added 1000 fungal species to the IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. The IUCN (Global) Conservation Status of Pavement Mushroom ( Agaricus bitorquis ) is: LC – Least Concern, with stable population. For more information, see on the following link

Agaricus bohusii.Description: This really tasty Agaric is still considered rare in most books but it seems to have become more common in the UK over the last few years. It grows in clusters so it’s found in large numbers but needs careful cleaning to remove all of the grit.
Agaricus bohusii.Cap: 8-12 cm. A firm capped mushroom with brown triangular scales that are distinctly pointed and raised. The caps are often covered in soil as they burst through the ground so rapidly.
Agaricus bohusii.Gills: Crowded and free from the stem. The gills start off white to pale pink and soon turn red brown to very dark brown.
Agaricus bohusii.Stem: 8-14 cm long, 1.5-2 cm diameter. The long stems have a tapered pointy base like a spindle and grow from a central point ,with the mushrooms in each cluster joined at the base of the stem. It starts with a whitish colour but often becomes brown, sometimes scaly below the ring. The flesh will bruise red brown if damaged.
Agaricus bohusii.Skirt: Has a thick, superior skirt that is usually towards the upper part of the stem. It is pale brown, scaly and can appear double ringed.
Agaricus bohusii.Flesh: Initially white but rapidly turning red-brown when exposed and then becoming darker brown.
Agaricus bohusii.Habitat: Growing from soil usually under trees in mixed woodland and parks.
Agaricus bohusii.Possible Confusion: The Inky Mushroom ( Agaricus moelleri ), pictured, is the most similar toxic species but this has a phenol/Indian ink/iodine smell to put you off, the flesh does not turn red and each mushroom grows individually from the soil and not from a central point.
Agaricus bohusii.Taste / Smell: Strong and mushroomy but the soil should be removed thoroughly otherwise a gritty meal will ensue. Should be cooked before consumption.
Agaricus bohusii.Frequency: It has been considered rare or at least uncommon, but in the last years we have seen an increase in appearances and it’s becoming more common. As it grows in dense clusters it wouldn’t be of any harm to pick a couple for a meal, but we must stress the importance of leaving more than half behind.

Agaricus campestris.Description: This used to be a very common mushroom but is becoming harder to find due to loss of habitat and the chemical sprays used nowadays.
Agaricus campestris.Cap: 5-8 cm. White, sometimes discoloured grey/brown, can be scaley or smooth. Starting spherical and opening out flat. Can bruise slightly pink. The cuticle often hangs down over the edge of the cap and is a good indicator of a Field Mushroom.
Agaricus campestris.Gills: Crowded and free from the stem. The gills start deep pink and soon turn to dark brown with maturity.
Agaricus campestris.Stem: 5-7 cm long, 1-2 cm diameter. White and smooth above the ring, slightly scaly below, tapering at the base. The ring is delicate and only traces of it can usually be found.
Agaricus campestris.Skirt: Superior to intermediate. Small, slight and not very long lasting.
Agaricus campestris.Habitat: Pasture, meadows, lawns, road verges and parks.
Agaricus campestris.Possible Confusion: The toxic Yellow Stainer ( Agaricus xanthodermus ), but this mushroom stains chrome yellow when bruised or cut and smells of Indian ink, hospitals or iodine.
Agaricus campestris.Spore Print: Chocolate brown. Ovoid. You should scrape your spores into a small pile to get an accurate spore colour.
Agaricus campestris.Taste / Smell: Mushroomy. Should be cooked before consumption.
Agaricus campestris.Frequency: Occasional but widespread, might be locally common, however becoming less so in fields that are sprayed with chemicals.
Agaricus campestris.Other Facts: In March 2025 the IUCN (International Union for Conservation of Nature) added 1000 fungal species to the IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. The IUCN (Global) Conservation Status of Field Mushroom ( Agaricus campestris ) is: LC – Least Concern, with stable population. For more information, see on the following link

Agaricus crocodilinus.Description: Occasional, but being a large mushroom can often be seen from a distance. Can easily be confused with the Horse Mushroom but both are great tasting mushrooms so it’s not a problem.
Agaricus crocodilinus.Average Cap width (CM): 10-16 but can be found up to 25cm
Agaricus crocodilinus.Cap: 10 to 25 cm when mature. Convex opening out flat becoming scaled and splitting at the edges when mature. Can remains of the veil hanging on the edges. Off-white sometimes with a pale yellow or brown flush.
Agaricus crocodilinus.Gills: Crowded and free of the stem. Starting pale pink and turning to brown then almost black.
Agaricus crocodilinus.Stem: 8-14 cm long, 2-3.5 cm diameter. White/cream and covered in floccules below the skirt. The stem tapers towards both the cap and base.
Agaricus crocodilinus.Skirt: Has a flimsy, superior skirt with floccules on the underside.
Agaricus crocodilinus.Flesh: White and firm, flushing red/pink in the stem when cut.
Agaricus crocodilinus.Habitat: Pastures, lawns and anywhere grassy. Growing in rings or sometimes individually.
Agaricus crocodilinus.Possible Confusion: The toxic Yellow Stainer ( Agaricus xanthodermus ), but this mushrooms flesh stains chrome yellow when bruised or cut and smells of phenol or Indian ink. The Horse Mushroom ( Agaricus arvensis ) looks similar but has a smooth stem, unlike the floccule covered stem, below the skirt, of the Macro Mushroom.
Agaricus crocodilinus.Taste / Smell: Mushroomy with a hint of almond or aniseed. Should be cooked before consumption. Smells of almonds to some, aniseed to others.
Agaricus crocodilinus.Other Facts: Even when young these are always full of maggots.

Agaricus langei.Description: A great tasting mushroom with flesh that bruises or oxidises red. Similar in looks to The Prince (Agaricus augustus), though smaller in size.
Agaricus langei.Cap: 5-15 cm. Spherical when young becoming convex. Covered in concentric slightly reddish brown scales on a white to pale yellow background.
Agaricus langei.Gills: Crowded. Free of the stem. Gills starting pink, maturing to dark brown.
Agaricus langei.Stem: 5-10 cm long, 1.5-3 cm diameter. White to pale cream with red hints, smooth above the skirt and covered in small brown scales below.
Agaricus langei.Skirt: A superior, single white fleshy ring hanging down with brown to grey floccules on the underside.
Agaricus langei.Flesh: White, bruising or oxidising to pink/red. Can be yellowish in the base of the stem in older specimens.
Agaricus langei.Possible Confusion: Inky Mushroom ( Agaricus moelleri ) , pictured, looks similar but the chemical, unpleasant smell of the flesh of this toxic mushroom and the fact its flesh doesn’t stain red should keep you safe. The Prince ( Agaricus augustus ) is similar but usually a lot larger and delicious so there is no harm confusing the two.

Agaricus moelleri.Description: A fairly common mushroom that can often be found in large numbers. When first spotted it usually causes a bit of excitement as it can resemble the Prince, then when smelt, disappointment sets in.
Agaricus moelleri.Cap: 7-10 cm. White but covered with tiny smoky/grey or brown scales which are more dense towards the middle. Starting ovoid but becoming flat.
Agaricus moelleri.Gills: Crowded and free of the stem. The gills start pink and stay like that until finally becoming dark brown/black.
Agaricus moelleri.Stem: 8-14 cm long, 1-1.2 cm diameter. White and slightly bulbous towards the base.
Agaricus moelleri.Skirt: Has a large, superior, membranous skirt.
Agaricus moelleri.Flesh: White discolouring slightly yellow and becoming brown.
Agaricus moelleri.Habitat: Mainly woodland in troops but can be found occasionally in grassland.

Agaricus phaeolepidus.Description: One of the brown scaled largeAgaricusspecies. It has a distinctive, superior, pendulous ring with a cogwheel pattern on its underside. Might be weakly yellowing, and have a phenolic smell.
Agaricus phaeolepidus.Cap: 5–12 cm across. Convex at first, then flattened. The skin is densely covered with light reddish brown to brown, appressed small scales. The centre of the cap usually darker than the rest.
Agaricus phaeolepidus.Gills: Crowded and free of the stem. Pinkish grey at first, then dark brown once the spores matured.
Agaricus phaeolepidus.Stem: 6–13 cm tall, 0.7–1.4 cm in diameter. White, cylindrical with a bulbous base. Its surface is smooth.
Agaricus phaeolepidus.Skirt: Superior, membranous, thin with a distinct cogwheel pattern on the margin of the underside.
Agaricus phaeolepidus.Flesh: Fairly thin, soft. Initially white, may slightly yellowing at the base of the stem, otherwise may or may not bruising to faint pinkish-brown or brownish.
Agaricus phaeolepidus.Habitat: Growing individually or in smaller groups on clay-rich or sandy calcareous soil in open deciduous woodlands, parks, gardens or cemeteries. Saprotrophic.
Agaricus phaeolepidus.Possible Confusion: It can be confused with other Agaricus species. Blushing Wood Mushroom ( Agaricus sylvaticus ), pictured, stains very red when cut, and has a weak, but pleasant ‘mushroomy’ or nutty smell. The Prince ( Agaricus augustus ) might yellow a bit in the cap and the stem, and has a strong and pleasant bitter almond smell. Tufted Wood Mushroom ( Agaricus impudicus ) bruising brown to reddish brown, and it has an unpleasant rubber-like smell.
Agaricus phaeolepidus.Taste / Smell: Inedible. It has a ‘mushroomy’ taste, but a weak, unpleasant, phenolic or carbolic smell (same as the Yellow Stainer or the Inky Mushroom, just weaker).
Agaricus phaeolepidus.Frequency: Rather rare in England and Wales.
Agaricus phaeolepidus.Spores: Spore print is dark brown. Spores ellipsoid, smooth, without germ-pore.
Agaricus phaeolepidus.Other Facts: It is often necessary to check our suspected ID with chemical tests (but this is not for novice foragers, due to the hazard of using chemical reagents). Dusky Scaled Mushroom is negative to Schäffer’s test (developed by Julius Schäffer, 1882–1944, German mycologist), and KOH gives a positive (yellow) reaction on the cap. The epithet (2nd part of the Scientific name) was created from a Greek and a Latin word. The Greek word ‘φαιός’ or ‘Phaiós’ means dusky, dark, grey, while the Latin word ‘Lepidus’ means pleasant, charming, pretty, pleasing etc. It indicates that we are looking for something which is pretty and grey or dusky.

Agaricus subrufescens.Description: ThisAgaricusspecies is native to North America and was regarded as a choice edible and cultivated. It is part of theAgaricussub section containing thehorse mushroom(Agaricus arvensis) andthe Prince. These all have an almondy smell. The almond mushroom occurs in large groups unlike the Prince which tends to occur in groups of 2 or 3.
Agaricus subrufescens.Cap: 3-10 cm. Convex, brown in the centre when young. Flattening with age with the brown splitting into scales
Agaricus subrufescens.Gills: Crowded and free from the stem. Grey in immature specimens, turning brown with age.
Agaricus subrufescens.Stem: 1-7 cm long, 1-2 cm diameter. Stout, slightly bulbous base, white, with cottony layer (easily compressed with handling) at the top.
Agaricus subrufescens.Skirt: Superior. Thick and floppy with woolly scales on the underside.
Agaricus subrufescens.Flesh: White, firm, thick. Smelling of almonds.
Agaricus subrufescens.Possible Confusion: As with all Agaricus sp. the toxic yellow stainer and inky mushroom are the ones to eliminate. The almond smell of Agaricus subrufescens will rule out both of these chemical smelling species.
Agaricus subrufescens.Other Facts: This mushroom was cultivated as a choice edible in the U.S.A

Agaricus sylvaticus.Description: An fairly easy to identify Agaric with its blushing stem and flesh.
Agaricus sylvaticus.Cap: 6-10 cm. Spherical when young becoming convex. Pale brown fibre-like lines turning into small scales over a paler background. Any bruising or damage to the cap turns almost immediately to a striking red colour, see photos above.
Agaricus sylvaticus.Gills: Crowded and free of the stem. Gills off-white becoming grey to red to dark brown.
Agaricus sylvaticus.Stem: 7-10 cm long, 1-1.2 cm diameter. White when young turning pale tan/grey. Can have a bulbous base.
Agaricus sylvaticus.Skirt: A large, superior,  skirt with triangular scales on the underside.
Agaricus sylvaticus.Flesh: White, staining very red when cut and eventually fading to brown.
Agaricus sylvaticus.Habitat: Coniferous woodland but can be found with deciduous trees.
Agaricus sylvaticus.Possible Confusion: Scaly Knight ( Tricholoma vaccinum ) has no ring and the gills are more red/brown. It is also edible but poor.
Agaricus sylvaticus.Taste / Smell: Excellent, mushroomy. Should be cooked before consumption.
Agaricus sylvaticus.Frequency: Common and widespread on the British Isles.
Agaricus sylvaticus.Other Facts: In March 2025 the IUCN (International Union for Conservation of Nature) added 1000 fungal species to the IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. The IUCN (Global) Conservation Status of Blushing Wood Mushroom ( Agaricus sylvaticus ) is: LC – Least Concern, with stable population. For more information, see on the following link

Agaricus sylvicola.Description: A tasty find but the mushrooms have a very short shelf life and need to be used soon after finding them.
Agaricus sylvicola.Cap: 8-12 cm. Off-white/cream bruising ochraceous and becoming yellow with age.
Agaricus sylvicola.Gills: Crowded and free of the stem. Gills pale grey/pink at first turning a dark chocolate brown.
Agaricus sylvicola.Stem: 8-14 cm long, 1-1.5 cm diameter. White/off-white with a pendulous ring and slightly bulbous base.
Agaricus sylvicola.Skirt: Superior. The underside is covered in triangular scales.
Agaricus sylvicola.Possible Confusion: The Yellow Stainer ( Agaricus xanthodermus ) looks very alike but bruises chrome yellow when handled or cut and smells of Indian ink, phenol, hospitals, just an unpleasant chemical smell.
Agaricus sylvicola.Taste / Smell: Smells of aniseed, to some slightly almondy. Taste mushroomy. Should be cooked before consumption.
Agaricus sylvicola.Other Facts: These mushrooms spoil very quickly and should be used the same day as picking them.

Agaricus xanthodermus.Description: Poisonous causing alarming symptoms but not affecting everybody. Not worth the chance!
Agaricus xanthodermus.Cap: 7-10 cm. Starting rounded but with a slightly cubed shape, this flattens to a round shallow convex. White with very small scales, the cap can crack and turn grey in dry, sunny conditions. The cap bruises chrome yellow quite quickly.
Agaricus xanthodermus.Gills: Crowded and free of the stem. Gills starting off white turning pink and becoming grey/brown when mature.
Agaricus xanthodermus.Stem: 8-14 cm long, 1-2 cm diameter. White/off-white with a skirt and slightly bulbous base.
Agaricus xanthodermus.Skirt: Has a superior, pendulous, double edged white skirt, the one in the image is stained on the top surface by spores.
Agaricus xanthodermus.Flesh: White bruising chrome yellow when cut especially at the base of the stem.
Agaricus xanthodermus.Habitat: Hedgerows, grassland, open woodland and beside roads and paths usually in large groups or rings.

Agrocybe praecox.Description: A common mushroom in Spring and early Summer but can be found later in the year. Although edible, the Spring Fieldcap is a little bitter and can be hard to identify to species among other Agrocybes.Agrocybe praecoxis a complex of four different species that are almost identical visually and only divisible with a microscope and scientific analyses.
Agrocybe praecox.Cap: 6-8 cm. Dark grey/brown and greasy when young becoming dryer, off white tan to ochre until drying to near white with age. Convex opening out to almost flat usually remaining smooth and cracking in dry conditions. Can have remains of the veil on the edges.
Agrocybe praecox.Gills: Crowded. Adnexed to almost free of the stem. Off white to pale grey to brown, becoming darker with age. Crowded with slightly wavy edges.
Agrocybe praecox.Cortina / Veil: The young mushroom has a veil covering the gills, this soon detaches and can become the delicate and short lasting skirt.
Agrocybe praecox.Stem: 8-10 cm tall, 0.4-1 cm wide . Off white, darkening slightly towards the base. Can have a small delicate skirt. Has visible mycelial threads attached to the base if removed from it’s medium.
Agrocybe praecox.Skirt: Superior. Has a thin, delicate, ephemeral skirt.
Agrocybe praecox.Habitat: Saprotrophic, grows on woodchip or soil in parks, gardens and paths.
Agrocybe praecox.Possible Confusion: There are various Agrocybe and Cyclocybe species that look similar, some should be avoided so we don’t eat this one. The Poplar fieldcap ( Cyclocybe cylindracea) is shown.
Agrocybe praecox.Taste / Smell: Bitter when raw, less so after cooking.
Agrocybe praecox.Other Facts: Agrocybe praecox is part of a complex of four Agrocybes that look almost identical and can only be identified by microscope or using chemical analysis.

Aleuria aurantia.Description: A very unusual, completely unmistakable, and edible mushroom.
Aleuria aurantia.Fruiting Body: No distinct cap, just a sheet of thin fragile bright orange flesh usually corrugated forming a rosette sometimes with multiple ‘petals’. Can be completely flat to the ground, or more upright becoming 5cm tall.
Aleuria aurantia.Gills: Does not have gills but the underside is paler than the upper surface and finely flocculose with a more matt finish.
Aleuria aurantia.Pores: Pores are too small to see with the naked eye but are on the upper surface of the cap to allow the spores to be released into the air and be blown away.
Aleuria aurantia.Stem: No real stem, more a very short thickening in the middle of the cap going into the ground.
Aleuria aurantia.Flesh: Very thin, same colour as underside of cap.
Aleuria aurantia.Habitat: Saprobic on grass, gravel, or soil, usually compacted such as the side of paths.
Aleuria aurantia.Possible Confusion: Some species from genus Peziza , pictured, can look similar but are brown to tan and never as bright orange as the Orange Peel Fungus. Pezizas are inedible not toxic. The Scarlet and Ruby Elfcup are similar but bright red. The Salmon Salad Fungus ( Guepinia helvelloides ), can look similar but is more a salmon pink than bright orange. It is edible but not worth eating so confusion would not be dangerous.
Aleuria aurantia.Frequency: Locally very common, where you find one you will likely find many.
Aleuria aurantia.Spores: White, ellipsoid. These are ejected from the upper surface of the cap in a rush when they are fully developed and the mushroom is knocked.

Amanita ceciliae.Description: One of the Grisette section within the broaderAmanitagenus. Typically a chunky mushroom, with the cap usually narrower than the length of the stem. It has no ring, emerges from a volva or sack structure, parts of which adhere to the cap. It is uncommon and its edibility is debatable, however it is very similar to other toxic species such as the panther cap so not recommended for the novice forager.
Amanita ceciliae.Cap: 8-14 cm. Chestnut brown with easily removed grey scales. Well defined striations around the edge and a pale margin in immature specimens. Starting ovoid, convex but flattening out with age.
Amanita ceciliae.Gills: Typical Amanita , crowded white gills, free from the stem.
Amanita ceciliae.Stem: 8-14 cm long, 1-2 cm diameter. No ring (as with all the Grisettes) but distinct shaggy grey zig-zag banding running across the stem – hence the term snakeskin.
Amanita ceciliae.Volva: It has a volva but this is fragile and collapses quickly
Amanita ceciliae.Habitat: Mycorrhizal with deciduous trees, often in a parkland setting.
Amanita ceciliae.Possible Confusion: The edibility of this mushroom is unclear, however the big potential for confusion here would be one of the other seriously poisonous Amanitas, particularly the Panthercap ( Amanita pantherina ) pictured. The Snakeskin Grissette does not have a skirt but these can be easily lost from look-a-like mushrooms leading to potential confusion. The stem of the Snakeskin Grisette should be a key identifier however this is not a mushroom for the novice forager!
Amanita ceciliae.Spore Print: White. Globose, smooth and colourless ( hyaline ).
Amanita ceciliae.Other Facts: The species name (epithet), ‘ ceciliae ‘ is honour of the Cecilia Berkeley, the wife of and contributor to the works of, the famous 19th century British mycologist, Miles Joseph Berkeley.

Amanita citrina var. alba.Description: Although this mushroom looks like a deadly Amanita it is edible if you like the taste of raw potatoes.
Amanita citrina var. alba.Cap: 6-10 cm. A pure white cap with white patches of veil that can discolour to a tan-oche.
Amanita citrina var. alba.Gills: Gills white, free of the stem and fairly crowded.
Amanita citrina var. alba.Stem: 7-11 cm long, 0.8-1.2 cm diameter. Pure white with an obvious volval sack and a bulbous base. The stem can be hollow in older specimens.
Amanita citrina var. alba.Skirt: Superior. The skirt is quite large.
Amanita citrina var. alba.Possible Confusion: The Destroying Angel ( Amanita virosa ), pictured, or the Deathcap ( Amanita phalloides ), it is because of this possible confusion and its vile taste that we leave this mushroom well alone. Although edible, not one for the table.

Amanita citrina var. citrina.Description: Although this mushroom looks like a deadly Amanita it is actually edible but not very nice and not worth the risk of confusion with deadly poisonous species.
Amanita citrina var. citrina.Cap: 6-10 cm. An ivory white to pale yellow cap covered in off white patches of the remains of the veil.
Amanita citrina var. citrina.Gills: Gills white, free of the stem and fairly crowded.
Amanita citrina var. citrina.Stem: 7-11 cm long, 0.8-1.2 cm diameter. Ivory white to yellow with an obvious volval sack and a bulbous base. The skirt is quite large and usually hangs down. The stem can be hollow in older specimens.
Amanita citrina var. citrina.Possible Confusion: The Destroying Angel ( Amanita virosa ), pictured, or the Deathcap ( Amanita phalloides ), it is because of this possible confusion and its vile taste that we leave this mushroom well alone. Although edible, not one for the table.

Amanita crocea.Description: ThisAmanitararely seems to have remains of the veil stuck to the cap and the colour intensity varies greatly and can be from bright orange to pale yellow.
Amanita crocea.Cap: 8-12 cm. Starting egg shaped and then opening out to almost flat with a slightly darker umbo and radial striations at the edge of the cap. The colour can vary quite a bit but is usually yellow to orange.
Amanita crocea.Gills: Crowded and free of the stem. White to Off white.
Amanita crocea.Stem: 8-14 cm long, 1-2 cm diameter. Pale orange with a snakeskin pattern, tapering towards the top.
Amanita crocea.Volva: Has a very obvious thick, long and white volval sack that can often be hidden under the surrounding vegetation or earth.
Amanita crocea.Habitat: Mycorrhizal, mainly grows with Birch or Beech , but can be found with some conifers.
Amanita crocea.Possible Confusion: The Tawny Grisette ( Amanita fulva ), pictured, can look similar as the A. crocea can vary quite a lot in colour but the Tawny Grisette has a plain, smooth stem unlike the zig zag patterns on the Orange Grisette.

Amanita excelsa.Description: This mushroom is not a safe mushroom for novice foragers as it can be difficult to distinguish it from the toxic Panthercap.
Amanita excelsa.Cap: 7-11 cm. Grey-silver coloured to light brown to a darker red/brown and covered in off-white to grey scales. Spherical to convex to flat.
Amanita excelsa.Gills: Crowded and free of the stem. White.
Amanita excelsa.Stem: 10-14 cm long, 1.5-2.5 cm diameter. White with an obvious skirt. The bottom of the stem is bulbous rather than appearing from a volva.
Amanita excelsa.Skirt: Superior. The skirt has obvious striations on the upper surface running up to the start of the gills. This is an important part of the identification to differentiate from the toxic Panthercap, the Panthercap’s skirt is smooth.
Amanita excelsa.Volva: More of a bulbous base than a volva. There is no ‘guttering’ at the top of the volva.
Amanita excelsa.Possible Confusion: The Panthercap ( Amanita pantherina ), pictured, this confusion can be avoided by very carefully studying the skirt on the stem. The Blusher ( Amanita rubescens ) looks similar but is edible.
Amanita excelsa.Spore Print: White. Ellipsoid. You should scrape your spores into a small pile to get an accurate spore colour.
Amanita excelsa.Taste / Smell: Mushroomy. Must be well cooked before consumption.

Amanita fulva.Description: A fairly easy to identify edibleAmanitabut great care should be taken when identifying any Amanitas. The Tawny Grisette must be cooked before consumption.
Amanita fulva.Cap: 8-12 cm. Orange/brown or ‘tawny’. Ovoid at first then flattening out with a slight, darker umbo. The edge of the cap has striations in line with the gills underneath.
Amanita fulva.Gills: Gills white, free of the stem and crowded. The gills can be different lengths terminating before reaching the cap edge or stem.
Amanita fulva.Stem: 8-12 cm long, 0.8-1.2 cm diameter. Starting white with a cap coloured flush developing when mature. Growing from an obvious sack like volva and tapering slightly towards the cap. No ring.
Amanita fulva.Volva: Has an obvious volval sack that can reach down a few centimetres into the earth.
Amanita fulva.Flesh: White, usually hollow in the stem.
Amanita fulva.Habitat: Mixed woodland, moorland and heaths particularly on acid soil.
Amanita fulva.Possible Confusion: The Grisette ( Amanita vaginata ) is similar but has a darker brown/grey cap. Care should always be taken when picking Amanitas for consumption. The Orange Grisette ( Amanita crocea ), pictured, can also look similar but has a more orange/yellow cap, the same coloured stem but with a zig zag pattern and slightly off white gills.
Amanita fulva.Other Facts: Must be cooked before consumption. The Tawny Grisette is mycorrhizal with quite a few different trees including, oak, birch, chestnut, alder, spruce and pine.

Amanita gemmata.Description: Poisonous, said to be deadly as with some otherAmanitaspecies. Uncommon.
Amanita gemmata.Cap: 6-10 cm. Convex to flat. Off-white, pale yellow covered in white pieces of velar remains or veil.
Amanita gemmata.Gills: Gills white, adnexed (slightly connected to stem), crowded.
Amanita gemmata.Stem: 7-11 cm long, 1-2 cm diameter. White, slightly yellowish. Bulbous at the base with a delicate volva sometimes hollowing in the middle.
Amanita gemmata.Skirt: Superior. A short lived, non striated skirt that is usually low down on the stem. Once gone, it usually leaves a small mark on the stem.
Amanita gemmata.Volva: Has a slightly bulbous base with an obvious volva.
Amanita gemmata.Flesh: White with pale yellow flush in the stem.
Amanita gemmata.Possible Confusion: Could potentially be confused with some of the yellow Russulas but Russulas don’t have a skirt or volva and have brittle gills. The Geranium Russula, ( Russula fellea ) is pictured.

Amanita muscaria.Description: A beautiful and photogenic mushroom that it is considered toxic but not deadly.
Amanita muscaria.Average Mushroom height (CM): 8-14 Though can be found much bigger occasionally.
Amanita muscaria.Average Cap width (CM): 8-14 Though can be found much bigger occasionally.
Amanita muscaria.Cap: 8-14 cm. Hemispherical at first when it can sometimes be more orangey than red, then opening flat with a bright red cap covered in white to yellow scales which are the remains of the volvic sack. The scales can be washed off during rain to leave a smooth red cap.
Amanita muscaria.Gills: Crowded and free of the stem. White to cream.
Amanita muscaria.Stem: 8-14 cm tall, 1-2 cm diameter. Appearing from a volva (a bulbous egg like structure) the stem is white with shaggy remains of the volva sticking to it, it also has a skirt higher up the stem.
Amanita muscaria.Skirt: Superior. Large, pendulous white/off white skirt, usually with yellow edges.
Amanita muscaria.Volva: Has a bulbous volva with shaggy rings of scales around it rather than being marginate or having a sac like structure.
Amanita muscaria.Habitat: Birch woods in particular but can be found in other mixed woodland.
Amanita muscaria.Possible Confusion: The Blusher ( Amanita rubescens ), pictured,  – where damaged shows pink red blushing,  has a striated ring and no striations on the margin of cap. While toxic raw it’s edible when cooked. The Grey Spotted Amanita ( Amanita excelsa ) – close relative of the Blusher, and fairly similar to it, without blushing and usually greyer colours. Although often not considered toxic it is not recommended. The Panthercap ( Amanita pantherina ) – very closely related to the Fly Agaric with a darker brown cap. It contains exactly the same toxins as the Fly Agaric, but in more variable and usually higher concentrations. The Jewelled Amanita ( Amanita gemmata ) – also closely related to the Fly Agaric and Panthercap, it could pass as a yellowish Fly Agaric (yellow forms of Fly Agaric exist). It might contain the same toxins as the other two but we couldn’t find enough reliable information. Like the Panthercap some books report it as very poisonous, it is wiser to avoid it.
Amanita muscaria.Spore Print: White. Ellipsoid. You should scrape your spores into a small pile to get an accurate spore colour.
Amanita muscaria.Other Facts: The common name of this mushroom comes from the medieval practice of breaking up the caps and leaving them in milk to stupefy flies. This mushroom also has hallucinogenic properties which the Lapps have used traditionally in ceremonies and even to round up reindeer who seem to love them.

Amanita pantherina.Description: An exciting find, this visually striking mushroom is not overly common. Poisonous, as with some otherAmanitaspecies it is often portrayed as deadly in field guides.
Amanita pantherina.Cap: 8-12 cm. Convex, flattening a bit with age. Dark brown to slightly red brown covered in thick white scales or ‘warts’ left from the veil of the volva.
Amanita pantherina.Gills: Crowded and free of the stem. White.
Amanita pantherina.Stem: 10-14 cm long, 1-2 cm diameter. White and shaggy under the skirt, smoother above.
Amanita pantherina.Skirt: Superior. The skirt does not have the striations or lines that the Blusher or Excelsa have and is smooth although in the photo the skirt is a bit dry and wrinkled but still striation free.
Amanita pantherina.Volva: Has an obvious, bulbous, marginate (with a ‘gutter’ running around the top edge) volva.
Amanita pantherina.Flesh: White, sometimes hollow in the stem.
Amanita pantherina.Habitat: Most types of woodland, particularly beech.
Amanita pantherina.Possible Confusion: The Blusher ( Amanita rubescens ), pictured, has off-white, often blushing warts on its cap, and it blushes all over the fruit body where it had been damaged or cut, also there are striations on the upper surface of its skirt. The Grey Spotted Amanita ( Amanita excelsa ) has off-white to grey warts or scales on its cap, and has striations on the upper surface of its skirt.
Amanita pantherina.Spore Print: White. Broadly ovate. You should scrape your spores into a small pile to get an accurate spore colour.
Amanita pantherina.Other Facts: Panthercap prefers acidic soil, while none of its potential lookalikes have this strong preference for acidic soil.

Amanita phalloides.Description: An innocuous looking mushroom that is among the most poisonous in the UK along with the Destroying Angel.
Amanita phalloides.Cap: 8-12 cm. Convex at first then opening and flattening. The cap colour can vary from olive green to dirty yellow or even tan brown. Slimy when wet but still looking shiny when dry.
Amanita phalloides.Gills: Crowded and free of the stem. White to cream.
Amanita phalloides.Stem: 10-14 cm long, 1-1.5 cm diameter. White with a  bulbous base and surrounded by a thin veil ( volva ) which is sack-like at ground height, tapering slightly towards the cap. The top of the volva will often be found attached to the stem more than halfway up, looking like a skirt.
Amanita phalloides.Skirt: Superior. White with obvious striations under the skirt sometimes visible on top.
Amanita phalloides.Volva: A very obvious deep volva that can be under the ground surface.
Amanita phalloides.Habitat: Most mixed woodland, particularly with oak and other deciduous trees.
Amanita phalloides.Spore Print: White. Ellipsoid to subglobose. You should scrape your spores into a small pile to get an accurate spore colour.
Amanita phalloides.Taste / Smell: DO NOT try any part of this mushroom.
Amanita phalloides.Frequency: Uncommon but can become more frequent some years when the conditions are right.
Amanita phalloides.Other Facts: The symptoms of Deathcap poisoning can start several hours after ingestion with severe vomiting, diarrhoea and abdominal pains and can last for a few days; this is followed by what seems to be a recovery for a few days but ending in death from kidney and liver failure. The main poison, alpha-amanitin, kills liver cells and passes through the kidneys to be recirculated and cause more damage. There are things that can be done to try and mitigate any harm from ingestion of the Deathcap while on the way to hospital. Excessive hydration with water can be very helpful as soon as possible. In hospital they can now sometimes treat the poisoning using an extract of milkthistle, if not, dialysis followed by new kidneys and possibly liver is the only option.

Amanita rubescens.Description: Common and available before many other species are out, this is a good eating mushroom but difficult to identify for the novice forager and must be well cooked before consumption. Great care should be taken identifying this fungi.
Amanita rubescens.Cap: 8-12 cm. Flesh coloured to light brown to a darker red/brown sometimes with a yellow flush and covered in off-white to grey scales. Spherical to convex to flat.
Amanita rubescens.Gills: Crowded and free of the stem. Can develop pink to red spots where damaged.
Amanita rubescens.Stem: 9-12 cm long, 1-2.5 cm diameter. Scaly and off white to grey/red/brown below the skirt, generally smoother and whiter above.
Amanita rubescens.Skirt: Superior. The skirt is an important identification tool as the top has fine grooves or striations running from the stem outwards.
Amanita rubescens.Volva: Young Blushers have an obvious volva but as the mushroom matures the bottom of the stem is bulbous rather than being marginate.
Amanita rubescens.Flesh: White but ‘blushing’ pink to red when bruised or exposed to air.
Amanita rubescens.Possible Confusion: Can be confused with the toxic Panthercap ( Amanita pantherina ), pictured. The main difference is that the Blusher has lines or striations on its skirt running from the stem out, the Panthercap skirt is smooth. Other differences are the Blusher has a lighter cap, the scales on the cap are off-white to grey rather than white, the Blusher stem is bulbous at the bottom the Panthercap growing from a volval sack and has a rim or ‘gutter’ at the top of the volva (marginate) and finally, the Blusher ‘blushes’ red when damaged or exposed to air. The Grey Spotted Amanita ( Amanita excelsa ), generally has a darker cap but is very similar looking but this should not be a problem as it is edible. Care should be taken when identifying Amanitas.
Amanita rubescens.Taste / Smell: Faint then becoming slightly acrid when fresh, tasty when cooked. Must be well cooked before eating as it contains a toxin that is destroyed when heated.

Amanita sect. Vaginatae.Description: From now on we use “Grisettes” as a colloquial term to refer all the ringless Amanita species (Amanitasect.Vaginatae). Their species level determination, based on macroscopic features only, is anything but easy and except for a few characteristic species, rather impossible. Thankfully there are a few features that help to recognise them as one of the Grisettes.All the Grisettes are medium or big size agarics (mushrooms with distinct cap, gills and stem), their cap is smooth (exceptSnakeskin Grisette(Amanita ceciliae) which has thick velar greyish patches on it, and a few other species in this group), margin of their cap is striated, gills are white to cream coloured, there is no ring or skirt around their stem which could be either smooth, covered with a snakeskin-like pattern or with small flakes. Their stem is cylindrical or slightly tapering towards the top of the stem (apex), their volva is saccate (looks like a sac) and very often remains in the soil if you try to pick it.Although they are considered edible, caution must be taken if foraging for this mushroom as it can look similar to aDeathcap(Amanita phalloides) or another toxic member of the genus.
Amanita sect. Vaginatae.Cap: The cap of all Grisettes starts ovate but will flatten out, usually retaining an umbo. The colour of the cap is really variable, from almost pure White to Beige, Brown or Grey, with a darker centre and striations at the edge of the cap in line with the gills below. Most of the Grisettes don’t usually have any remains of the volva sticking to the cap.
Amanita sect. Vaginatae.Gills: The gills are generally White, but sometimes they could be Cream coloured too. They are crowded and usually free of the stem although they can be adnexed, (slightly joined to the stem).
Amanita sect. Vaginatae.Stem: The colour of the stem is mostly rather similar to the cap’s colour. It is very often smooth, but sometimes it could have a snakeskin pattern on. Commonly cylindrical, but can be tapering slightly towards the apex (top of the stem).
Amanita sect. Vaginatae.Volva: Has a sack like volva that can be hidden in the undergrowth.
Amanita sect. Vaginatae.Flesh: Thin, white and can become hollow in the stem.
Amanita sect. Vaginatae.Habitat: Associated with different broadleaved and coniferous trees, in some locations with small shrubs or herbaceous plants.
Amanita sect. Vaginatae.Possible Confusion: The Deathcap ( Amanita phalloides ), pictured, can look similar but has a skirt, this is not however a reliable form of ID as the skirt can be missing or damaged. The Tawny Grisette ( Amanita fulva ) is very similar but is a tan/orange colour. The Orange Grisette ( Amanita crocea ) is an orange colour and is usually larger.
Amanita sect. Vaginatae.Other Facts: Although Amanita vaginata is called the Grisette, there is no consensus on what exact species we should call Amanita vaginata , so this page depicts the general aspects of close lookalike species in Amanita section Vaginatae . Despite Grisettes being edible we do not recommend them for novices, because they can easily be confused with other Amanitas (incl. toxic species) and most of the Grisettes do not have a remarkable taste so unless you are desperate and 100% sure of the identification they are best left alone.

Amanita strobiliformis.Description: A very robust (chunky) rare whiteAmanita. Large, solid, and almost clublike before the cap opens. This is a mushroom that can be spotted from a hundred metres away and with care identified despite there being a number of whiteAmanita.
Amanita strobiliformis.Cap: 10–20 cm in diameter when opened, starting off domed and flattening out with maturity. White or off white with large dirty grey lumps of veil attached. These hang around and off the edge.
Amanita strobiliformis.Gills: Very white, crowded, adnexed (gills attached with less than full depth to stem) which is unusual for the Amanita genus which are usually free.
Amanita strobiliformis.Cortina / Veil: Fragments of the veil adhere to the cap and margins of the cap as large grey scales
Amanita strobiliformis.Stem: 10–20 cm long, 2–5 cm diameter. Very substantial and club like, white, rough and mealy. There is no substantial volva like some Amanita but there are flaky remnants ringing the bottom of the stem.
Amanita strobiliformis.Skirt: The skirt is quite large but very insubstantial almost lacy and high up the stem (superior). It is easily broken by handling or disturbance reducing it to a short fragment sitting on the stem.
Amanita strobiliformis.Possible Confusion: In foraging terms this closely resembles many other deadly Amanita. However the more common Amanita , like the Deathcap ( Amanita phalloides ) or the Destroying Angel ( Amanita virosa ), pictured, all have white forms but have obvious volva and less substantial scales. There are several uncommon Amanita / Saproamanita that are very similar, but again these have either obvious volva, are less robust, or inhabit different habitats.
Amanita strobiliformis.Other Facts: There are suggestions that this could be edible (and also some suggestions that it contains many of the same toxins as the other toxic Amanita ), however bearing in mind its close resemblance to several deadly species and a number of possibly slightly less deadly species it is not one to be regarded as recommended any time soon!

Amanita virosa.Description: A beautiful but deadly mushroom causing the same symptoms asAmanita phalloides. Fairly rare.
Amanita virosa.Cap: 7-11 cm. Convex then conical to almost flat but usually retaining an umbo. The cap is pure white and can be viscid.
Amanita virosa.Gills: Crowded and free of the stem. White.
Amanita virosa.Stem: 10-14 cm long, 1-1.5 cm diameter. White with a fibrous skin. As with other Amanitas the stem starts from a bulbous volva but the skirt is fragile and often missing or slight.
Amanita virosa.Skirt: Superior. A slight skirt with no striations which can be easily damaged or missing.
Amanita virosa.Volva: A large bulbous volva that can be deep under the surface.
Amanita virosa.Taste / Smell: DO NOT try any of this mushroom.
Amanita virosa.Other Facts: The symptoms of Destroying Angel poisoning can start several hours after ingestion with severe vomiting, diarrhoea and abdominal pains and can last for a few days; this is followed by what seems to be a recovery for a few days but ending in death from kidney and liver failure. The main poison, alpha-amanitin, kills liver cells and passes through the kidneys to be recirculated and cause more damage. There are things that can be done to try and mitigate any harm from ingestion of the Destroying Angel while on the way to hospital. Excessive hydration with water can be very helpful as soon as possible. In hospital they can now sometimes treat the poisoning using an extract of milkthistle, if not, dialysis followed by new kidneys and possibly liver is the only option.

Armillaria mellea.Description: This tasty and very common mushroom can give a small amount of people gastric upsets so should be tried in small amounts the first time it is eaten. It should always be cooked before consumption.
Armillaria mellea.Cap: 5-12 cm. Conical when young, then convex, then flattening and even having upturned edges. Honey coloured, ochre or brown with a darker slight umbo and sometimes concentric circles of darker scales.
Armillaria mellea.Gills: Crowded. Adnate to slightly decurrent. Gills start white turning yellow to brown and often darker.
Armillaria mellea.Stem: 8-14 cm long, 0.5-1.5 cm diameter. The chunky Honey fungus has a fairly thick, scaly, white to yellow brown stem which is usually bulbous at the base. The slender fungus is thinner, generally smoother and tapers towards the base and can be white to yellow to red/brown.
Armillaria mellea.Skirt: Superior. The ring is usually very high on the stem and can appear as a double ring with chrome yellow edges.
Armillaria mellea.Habitat: Growing in large clusters on deciduous trunks, stumps or dead wood but can also be found in grass as the rhizomorphs spread looking for more trees to infect.
Armillaria mellea.Possible Confusion: Galerina marginata , pictured, can look similar but is darker and has a distinct smell which is not mushroomy. Care should be taken with the identification of this fungi as Galerina marginata is also called The Funeral Bell . The Shaggy Scalycap ( Pholiota squarrosa ) can look similar but has brown spores and has much more pronounced scales on the cap as well as scales on the stem which the Honey Fungus doesn’t have.
Armillaria mellea.Taste / Smell: Good and found in large numbers. Must be cooked before consumption but can still cause slight gastric upsets in a small number of people.
Armillaria mellea.Other Facts: This mushroom is responsible for killing many trees and the rhizomorphs or ‘bootlaces’ can usually be found under the clusters of fungi and surrounding bark. Unlike most mushrooms this fungi can live on its host tree alive or dead and can spread under ground easily and ends up killing its host. Armillaria do not grow from spores very easily. An  Armillaria has formed what is thought to be the largest living single organism on the planet and has been reported at 3.4 square miles in size and thousands of years old.

Aspropaxillus giganteus.Description: A large chunky mushroom which can be found in fairly large numbers and is edible to most but can cause gastric upsets in some. This doesn’t really matter as the mushrooms are usually infested with maggots, even when young, making them more maggot than flesh.
Aspropaxillus giganteus.Synonyms: Leucopaxillus giganteus, Paxillus giganteus, Clitocybe gigantea
Aspropaxillus giganteus.Cap: 10–40 cm. The cap starts ivory white and convex but soon flattens out with a downward turned edge before becoming funnel shaped and turning a tan/off white colour. This mushroom can be very varied in size with the cap measuring from ten to forty five cm across with the larger specimens being rarer.
Aspropaxillus giganteus.Gills: The gills are decurrent (running down the stem) and forked. White and crowded becoming off white with age.
Aspropaxillus giganteus.Stem: 4–8 cm long, 2.5-4 cm diameter. Thick, can be up to 5cm. White with vertical ‘fibres’ which can discolour to tan.
Aspropaxillus giganteus.Flesh: White, fairly tough and usually full of maggots.
Aspropaxillus giganteus.Habitat: Open woodland and hedgerows, grassland and beside country lanes.
Aspropaxillus giganteus.Possible Confusion: The Fleecy Milkcap, pictured, can look very similar but produces latex from the gills and flesh, unlike the Giant Funnel. The Trooping Funnel can look similar but has a much longer stem, an umbo in the middle of the cap, is more tan coloured and does not produce latex. Some members of genus Clitocybe can look like the Giant Funnel but the clue is in the name, the cap can be up to forty+ cm in diameter with a short, thick stem distinguishing it from most of the Clitocyboid species.
Aspropaxillus giganteus.Other Facts: This mushroom is reported as edible but can cause gastric upsets in some people so it is best to try just a small amount well cooked if it your first time trying them.

Auricularia auricula-judae.Description: Very common and can be found year round. Usually most abundant in January and February when there is not much else about.
Auricularia auricula-judae.Fruiting Body: 3-7cm. The fruiting body is ear-shaped. It is smooth or undulating, covered in very fine down and is tan, red/brown in colour.
Auricularia auricula-judae.Pores: The underside is smoother and lighter than the top surface.
Auricularia auricula-judae.Habitat: Mainly growing on dead or living elder in large numbers but can be found occasionally on other wood.
Auricularia auricula-judae.Possible Confusion: As long as you only collect these from elder trees they can only be Jelly Ears. Some Pezizas, pictured, can look similar but these don’t tend to grow on elder and grow with the ‘cup shape’ facing up, the Jelly Ears face down. listening to the ground.
Auricularia auricula-judae.Taste / Smell: Not strong but good if used in Asian style cooking or dried, ground to a fine powder and used as stock.
Auricularia auricula-judae.Frequency: Very common and widespread in the UK.
Auricularia auricula-judae.Other Facts: Can be picked in its dry state and re-hydrated when needed or picked fresh and dried at home. Can withstand frosts and grows all year round. Named after the apostle, Judas, who allegedly hanged himself from an Elder tree. Until recently the common English names Jelly Ear and Wood Ear were used interchangeably in the English speaking world. However, in the light of the recent taxonomic changes within the genus Auricularia , we would recommend to stick to the recommended common English name by the British Mycological Society, which is Jelly Ear. Our Jelly Ear ( Auricularia auricula-judae ) is a European species, and it is not native to Asia, while Wood Ear ( Auricularia heimuer ) is native to Asia, and it is not native to Europe. They could be used in the same way in the kitchen, but they are two different species now.

Auricularia mesenterica.Description: An inedible relative of ourJelly Ear. From the top, it might remind you ofTurkeytail, but once you have checked its underneath, everything becoming clear.
Auricularia mesenterica.Fruiting Body: 1–3 cm across. The fruiting body is ear shaped, often resupinate (covers the substrate without forming a cap) or semi-resupinate (only forms a small cap), often forms fused-emerged big patches on the substrate. Upper surface is irregular, wavy or lobed, hairy (often covered with algae) and zonated. Its margin is grey-white, the concentric zones are reddish-brown, grey, ochre and/or white in colour.
Auricularia mesenterica.Gills: Does not have gills. The fertile (under) surface is smooth when young, becoming wrinkled or vein-like with age. Whitish or pale grey at first, darkening to reddish-brown when mature.
Auricularia mesenterica.Flesh: Thin, gelatinous, soft when young and moist, becoming tough and somewhat brittle with age.
Auricularia mesenterica.Habitat: Saprotrophic, causing white-rot. Growing on dead wood and stumps of various hardwood genera the whole year long if the environmental conditions are right, but in the UK the most common substrates are Elm and Beech . The individual fruit bodies often emerge and form a big patch of tripe fungus on its substrate.
Auricularia mesenterica.Possible Confusion: Jelly Ear ( Auricularia auricula-judae ), has smooth, faintly hairy skin, concolorous with its fertile underside. Turkeytail ( Trametes versicolor ), pictured, has a rather similarly zonated top, but has less hairy skin, and has a white pore surface. Crusts ( Stereum spp.) have thin, leathery flesh and their fertile underside is never wrinkled or vein-like.
Auricularia mesenterica.Spore Print: Spore print is white. Spores are cylindrical, colourless ( hyaline ), smooth with drops.
Auricularia mesenterica.Taste / Smell: Inedible, smell and taste not distinctive.
Auricularia mesenterica.Frequency: Frequent and widespread on the British Isles. Fruiting everywhere with enough decaying hardwood, e.g., parklands, woodlands, gardens, etc.
Auricularia mesenterica.Other Facts: The genus name, Auricularia , refers to the ear shape of the species within the genus. The epithet (the 2nd part of the scientific name which identifies the species within the genus) mesenterica has Greek origin (mesenterion or μεσεντέριον) and refers to the ‘middle of the intestine’ or tripe.

Bjerkandera adusta.Description: A very common, small, annual polypore mushroom with grey pore surface.
Bjerkandera adusta.Fruiting Body: 3–7 cm across, thin, convex to nearly flat, fan-shaped or shelf-like, often overlapping or even rosette-like, usually in groups. It could be resupinate if growing on the underside of the host/substrate. Margin is white, blackening with age. Its skin is faintly hairy ( tomentose ) with faint concentric zones at first, could be almost completely hairless and suede-like with age.
Bjerkandera adusta.Pores: Tubes up to 1 mm long, pale grey to grey. Pores 4–7 per mm, angular to irregularly rounded, smoke-grey, blackening if damaged.
Bjerkandera adusta.Flesh: Thin, elastic and has two layers. Under the skin it is whitish, while greyish to blackish above the tubes.
Bjerkandera adusta.Habitat: On the dead wood of hardwoods, especially Beech , but rarely on conifers. Saprotrophic, causes white-rot.
Bjerkandera adusta.Possible Confusion: Especially younger fruit bodies could be easily confuse with Turkeytail ( Trametes versicolor ), pictured, but its skin has more colour and its pore surface is much brighter white. Its close relative, Big Smoky Bracket ( Bjerkandera fumosa ) somewhat bigger (4–10 cm across), its cap is paler in colour and growing mostly on Sycamore, but also on Alder, Sweet Chestnut or other hardwood genera. There is a dark layer between the two layers of its flesh.
Bjerkandera adusta.Spore Print: Spore print is white. Spores elliptical, smooth and colourless ( hyaline ).
Bjerkandera adusta.Taste / Smell: Inedible, tastes sour, but it has a somewhat sweet smell.

Boletus / Butyriboletus appendiculatus.Description: A great and usually large mushroom, almost as good as the Penny Bun with a firm texture.
Boletus / Butyriboletus appendiculatus.Cap: 7-10 cm. Rusty to red brown or sometimes lighter, often irregular, sometimes has a ‘cracked’ skin especially near the centre.
Boletus / Butyriboletus appendiculatus.Pores: Lemon yellow, tight sponge like pores that darken a bit with age. These will bruise to a blue colour.
Boletus / Butyriboletus appendiculatus.Stem: 7-10 cm long, 3-4 cm diameter. Straight or clavate, club shaped, lemon yellow at the top with yellow reticulation, (a mesh or net like covering) then usually a change to a pale orange to red towards the base.
Boletus / Butyriboletus appendiculatus.Flesh: White to pale yellow. Turning pale blue when cut, the base bruising rusty brown.
Boletus / Butyriboletus appendiculatus.Habitat: Mainly around Oak but will grow with other deciduous trees.
Boletus / Butyriboletus appendiculatus.Possible Confusion: Other Boletes. Although the Oak Bolete is quite distinctive care should be taken when trying to identify this mushroom as it breaks the simple edible rules for Boletes (if a bolete has red on it anywhere, do not eat it and if it stains blue when cut, again, don’t eat it).

Boletus / Caloboletus calopus.Description: Although not poisonous, this mushroom will ruin any dish you put it in due to its extreme bitterness.
Boletus / Caloboletus calopus.Cap: 7-10 cm. Cloudy grey with some tan hints. Starting a bit downy but becoming smooth with age. Can crack towards the centre.
Boletus / Caloboletus calopus.Pores: Lemon yellow, tight, sponge like pores which bruise a pale blueish green.
Boletus / Caloboletus calopus.Stem: 7-10cm long, 3-4.5 cm diameter. Lemon yellow at the top going into red and finally brown at the bottom, this is covered in a light coloured reticulation. The stem can vary from swollen to slim and has traces of ‘roots’ when pulled up.
Boletus / Caloboletus calopus.Flesh: Pale yellow but turning immediately off white on cutting and changing to blue after a short time.
Boletus / Caloboletus calopus.Habitat: Beech and oak but will grow with other deciduous trees, sometimes conifers.
Boletus / Caloboletus calopus.Possible Confusion: Other Boletes, particularly the Rooting Bolete ( Caloboletus radicans ), pictured.

Boletus / Caloboletus radicans.Description: Although not poisonous this mushroom is so bitter it will ruin any dish you put it in.
Boletus / Caloboletus radicans.Cap: 7-12 cm. Off white to grey/brown, darkening with age. Can get very big and uneven and will show cracking on the surface of the cap.
Boletus / Caloboletus radicans.Pores: Has yellow, tight, sponge like pores which bruise blue.
Boletus / Caloboletus radicans.Stem: 7-10  long, 3-4 cm diameter . Lemon yellow at the top becoming pale red or brown and ‘dirtier’ towards the swollen, slightly rooting base. The stem has a light coloured reticulation which is easiest to see towards the apex.
Boletus / Caloboletus radicans.Flesh: Yellow when first cut but quickly changing to off white in the cap and then turning blue.
Boletus / Caloboletus radicans.Habitat: Usually with oak and beech but will grow with other deciduous trees.
Boletus / Caloboletus radicans.Possible Confusion: Other Boletes, particularly Bitter Beech Bolete ( Caloboletus calopus ), pictured.

Boletus / Chalciporus piperatus.Description: This mushroom can be dried and ground and used as a pepper like condiment or eaten cooked by people who like hot chillies.
Boletus / Chalciporus piperatus.Cap: 5-8 cm. Cinnamon to brown,  shiny even when dry and can crack with age.
Boletus / Chalciporus piperatus.Pores: Angular, cinnamon to brown pores. Unchanging when bruised.
Boletus / Chalciporus piperatus.Stem: 6-9 cm long, 0.5-2 cm diameter. Fairly thin for a Bolete, yellow to cinnamon coloured with hints of red and vertically striated. The stem is chrome yellow at the base but this can often be covered by earth.
Boletus / Chalciporus piperatus.Flesh: Yellow with a slight reddish flush in the cap, chrome yellow at the very base of the stem.
Boletus / Chalciporus piperatus.Habitat: With Birch or Pine and often found in association with where Fly Agarics grow.
Boletus / Chalciporus piperatus.Possible Confusion: A small nibble on this Bolete will soon give its identity away due to its hot peppery taste.

Boletus / Gyroporus castaneus.Description: This is a great mushroom to find because if you look around nearby, there will usually be many more underfoot.The Chestnut Bolete is distinguished from true Boletes by its pale yellow spore print and the hollow stem.
Boletus / Gyroporus castaneus.Cap: 3-8 cm. Pale orange to tawny to darker brown coloured starting convex but soon flattening out. Downy when young becoming smooth. When the mushroom becomes old it usually discolours white from the attack of a mould, the Boletus Eater ( Hypomyces chrysospermus ).
Boletus / Gyroporus castaneus.Pores: White pores that discolour to off-white/pale yellow with age and bruise pale grey.
Boletus / Gyroporus castaneus.Stem: 3-8 cm long, 1-2.5 cm diameter. Off-white to pale orange to chestnut coloured with white flesh. The stem becomes hollow in most specimens.
Boletus / Gyroporus castaneus.Flesh: White and unchanging when exposed to air, very occasionally with a pink flush.
Boletus / Gyroporus castaneus.Habitat: Usually with oaks or sweet chestnut but will grow with other hardwoods in woods, gardens, parks and verges.
Boletus / Gyroporus castaneus.Possible Confusion: It can be easily distinguished from other boletes by its white pores, brittle flesh and hollow stem, therefore it’s an easy one for British foragers to identify.
Boletus / Gyroporus castaneus.Taste / Smell: Mushroomy but not strong. Must be cooked before consumption.
Boletus / Gyroporus castaneus.Frequency: Uncommon, can be found locally in the South of England.
Boletus / Gyroporus castaneus.Other Facts: It has been reported that a small amount of people have experienced gastric upsets after consuming these mushrooms.

Boletus / Hortiboletus bubalinus.Description: The genus name,Hortiboletus, refers to the latin ‘hortus‘ meaning garden where theHortiboletus bubalinuscan often be found growing with Poplar orLime trees.
Boletus / Hortiboletus bubalinus.Synonyms: Boletus bubalinus, Xerocomus bubalinus, Xerocomellus bubalinus
Boletus / Hortiboletus bubalinus.Cap: 6-10 cm. Pale brown with slight red or yellow hues, lighter towards the edge. Starts of rounded but becoming flatter and more uneven with age.
Boletus / Hortiboletus bubalinus.Pores: Yellow to pale yellow sometimes with olivaceous hints. Angular not round and bruising blue/green.
Boletus / Hortiboletus bubalinus.Stem: 6-10 cm long, 1-1.5 cm diameter. Fairly thin for a Bolete, pale background covered in vertical red ‘fibres’.
Boletus / Hortiboletus bubalinus.Flesh: Off white/yellow in the stem. White in the cap staining pink under the cuticle and blue above the pores.
Boletus / Hortiboletus bubalinus.Habitat: Often in parks, gardens and urban environments under Lime or Poplar trees.
Boletus / Hortiboletus bubalinus.Possible Confusion: Other Boletes but none of the poisonous varieties.
Boletus / Hortiboletus bubalinus.Frequency: Not reported much before 2000 but becoming more common or more often reported.
Boletus / Hortiboletus bubalinus.Other Facts: Was Boletus bubalinus then becoming Xerocomus then Xerocomellus before, for now anyway, settling with Hortiboletus .

Boletus / Hortiboletus rubellus.Description: These are fairly rare mushrooms in the UK and as they also have a soapy taste they are best left for photographs.
Boletus / Hortiboletus rubellus.Synonyms: Boletus versicolor, Boletus rubellus, Xerocomellus rubellus
Boletus / Hortiboletus rubellus.Cap: 6-8 cm. Scarlet red fading to olivaceous red, dry and slightly velvety. Starting convex but flattening out with age.
Boletus / Hortiboletus rubellus.Pores: Yellow angular pores that fade a bit greenish with age and bruise blue slowly.
Boletus / Hortiboletus rubellus.Stem: 6-10 cm long, 1-1.5 cm diameter. Red and striated with a more yellow apex and yellow mycelial threads.
Boletus / Hortiboletus rubellus.Flesh: Yellowish staining blue when cut with red to pink just under the cap cuticle.
Boletus / Hortiboletus rubellus.Habitat: Grassy woodland or or parks and gardens particularly with oak sometimes with beech.
Boletus / Hortiboletus rubellus.Possible Confusion: A fairly distinctive mushroom with a couple of rare lookalikes in the Bolete family.

Boletus / Imleria badia.Description: The Bay Bolete is a great mushroom and not far from thePenny Bunin gastronomic value. So much so, we could not differentiate between the two in a blind taste test, with only the less firm texture of the Bay Bolete giving it away.
Boletus / Imleria badia.Cap: 5-8 cm. Often starts spherical opening to convex and flattening with age. A bit velvety when young, smooth and shiny when mature. Dark brown or brown/brick coloured, slightly slimy when wet.
Boletus / Imleria badia.Pores: Pale yellow pores , bruising rapidly to a blue/green.
Boletus / Imleria badia.Stem: 5-8 cm long, 1-4 cm diameter. Pale brown looking vertically fibrous over a paler yellow/tan background. Can be quite thick.
Boletus / Imleria badia.Flesh: White/pale yellow. Staining pale blue/green on cutting especially in the cap.
Boletus / Imleria badia.Possible Confusion: Can look like other Boletes (see Penny Bun , pictured,) but if you stick to the simple rule of avoiding any Bolete with red on the stem, pores or cap and any Bolete whose flesh turns rapidly blue when cut you will only pick edible Boletes. You will be missing out on some good edibles with that rule but you will be keeping yourself 100% safe.
Boletus / Imleria badia.Taste / Smell: Good when fresh with the pores removed, better when dried.
Boletus / Imleria badia.Frequency: Very common and widespread in the UK.
Boletus / Imleria badia.Other Facts: A great find as Bay Boletes don’t often host maggots. In March 2025 the IUCN (International Union for Conservation of Nature) added 1000 fungal species to the IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. The IUCN (Global) Conservation Status of Bay Bolete ( Imleria badia ) is: LC – Least Concern, with stable population. For more information, see on the following link

Boletus / Leccinum albostipitatum.Description: A scarce member of theLeccinumgenus of the Boletes. Very similar to and probably often mistaken for theOrange Bolete,Leccinum aurantiacum. Usually found in small groups, a very solid and quite tall mushroom with a distinctive orange coloured cap and and a pale stem. Like other orange capped boletes needs thorough cooking.
Boletus / Leccinum albostipitatum.Cap: 5-10 cm. Orangey red, domed even in mature specimens. Flaps of skin hanging over the edge up to 6mm lasting into maturity.
Boletus / Leccinum albostipitatum.Pores: Off white to grey small round pores.
Boletus / Leccinum albostipitatum.Stem: 7-20 cm long and 2-5vcm diameter. Proportionally long. Very solid, tapering towards the cap. White with floccules (small raised protrusions found on the stem of the Leccinum genus). These floccules can be a gingery/foxy colour in some areas, but never dense dark brown. Base can be swollen and blue.
Boletus / Leccinum albostipitatum.Flesh: Firm, thick. White at first, then sometimes turning wine red, then greys to almost black. Sometimes turning blue in the base.
Boletus / Leccinum albostipitatum.Habitat: Associates with Populus species, i.e, various Poplars and Aspens.
Boletus / Leccinum albostipitatum.Possible Confusion: The Orange Bolete ( Leccinum aurantiacum ) is very very similar. The stem has darker ‘ floccules ‘, and the cap is a redder, more foxy colour.
Boletus / Leccinum albostipitatum.Other Facts: This has been known by the name Leccinum aurantiacum for many years due to a mistake by the original scientist who described it. Later studies decided that this was incorrect and taxonomic law meant that the name had to be applied to a different mushroom – so a new name was given to this species. All very confusing, but new work has clarified the matter.

Boletus / Leccinum aurantiacum.Description: Although known to be associated with Oak, this mushroom can also be found under Poplar, Aspen, Beech or Birch,  making the identification between other Leccinums difficult. Must be well cooked before consumption.
Boletus / Leccinum aurantiacum.Cap: 7-15 cm. Fox orange/brown but light blue/green where damaged. Starting ovate opening to broadly convex and staying like that until finally flattening out a bit with age, can be slightly downy especially when young. The top edge of the cap overhangs the pores which can help with identification.
Boletus / Leccinum aurantiacum.Pores: Off white to cream quite tightly packed pores which can bruise grey with a slight pink hue.
Boletus / Leccinum aurantiacum.Stem: 12-18 cm long, 1.5-4 cm diameter. Off white background covered in orange/brown floccules. Usually starts quite bulbous and short but thins out and elongates becoming almost straight with age.
Boletus / Leccinum aurantiacum.Flesh: White when first cut but turning dark grey with hints of purple after a couple of minutes.
Boletus / Leccinum aurantiacum.Habitat: Grows with Oaks but can more often be found with Poplar or Aspen and can also be found with Beech and Birch .
Boletus / Leccinum aurantiacum.Possible Confusion: Orange Birch Bolete ( Leccinum versipelle ), pictured, is very similar but only grows with Birch, has a lighter cap colour and has dark brown to black floccules on the stem unlike the orange/brown floccules of the Orange Bolete.
Boletus / Leccinum aurantiacum.Taste / Smell: A good tasting firm fleshed mushroom. Must be well cooked before consumption.

Boletus / Leccinum duriusculum.Description: A fairly large bolete associated with poplar and one of Attila’s favourites since childhood. Like all theLeccinumspecies, it should be cooked well!
Boletus / Leccinum duriusculum.Cap: 7–15 cm across, sub-spherical, then convex to flattened, its margin often projecting a little. Its skin is finely downy to smooth, pale brown, buff, ochre-brown to grey-brown, often cracking with age.
Boletus / Leccinum duriusculum.Pores: Whitish cream, to greyish-brown, bruising buff-brown. The pores are very small.
Boletus / Leccinum duriusculum.Stem: 5–15 cm long, 2–5 cm diameter. Robust, cylindrical, spindle-shape ( fusiform ) or swollen around the middle ( ventricose ). Whitish with dark grey-black squamules, in a net-like pattern. The top of the stem ( apex ) is often paler, bruising light brownish when touched. Stem base stains blue-green.
Boletus / Leccinum duriusculum.Flesh: White to off white, turning pink to violaceous when cut, after a few minutes it turns a darker grey to black. Might be staining blue in maggot holes. It is thick, firm to soft in the cap, fibrous in the stem.
Boletus / Leccinum duriusculum.Habitat: Ectomycorrhizal, associated with Poplars. Growing solitary or more commonly in groups from early Summer to mid-Autumn. Prefers open woodlands, parks and cemeteries.
Boletus / Leccinum duriusculum.Possible Confusion: It could be confused with other Leccinum species, but as all of them are edible after thorough cooking, this won’t cause any problems.
Boletus / Leccinum duriusculum.Spore Print: Light olive brown. Spores are fusiform, ellipsoid, colourless ( hyaline ) and smooth with droplets.
Boletus / Leccinum duriusculum.Taste / Smell: A choice edible that has an excellent taste, especially if dehydrated first. It has a pleasant smell.
Boletus / Leccinum duriusculum.Frequency: Widespread but occasional in the South and Southeast.

Boletus / Leccinum scabrum.Description: This common edible Autumn mushroom is not as firm and tasty as the best boletes, but mixed with other mushrooms it’s not bad. Because it’s a very common mushroom it can really help to bulk your basket and it’s a really easy one for beginners.
Boletus / Leccinum scabrum.Cap: 7-10 cm. Smooth, starting hemispherical and flattening with age. Varying shades of brown. Sticky when wet.
Boletus / Leccinum scabrum.Pores: White to white/greyish pores discolouring with age and bruising brown.
Boletus / Leccinum scabrum.Stem: 8-13 cm long, 1.5-3 cm diameter. White to grey with a covering of small dark scales or floccules , giving it a dirty appearance. Tapering towards the top.
Boletus / Leccinum scabrum.Flesh: White, unchanging when cut or turning slightly pink but turning black when cooked.
Boletus / Leccinum scabrum.Possible Confusion: The Slate Bolete (leccinum duriusculum), pictured, is very similar but grows in association with Poplars not Birch as the Brown Birch Bolete does. Other Leccinums, there are a few with brown caps which can be hard to distinguish but none of these Leccinums are poisonous. The orange cap Leccinums are toxic when raw and should be cooked for at least 15 minutes (see Orange Birch Bolete and Orange Oak Bolete ).
Boletus / Leccinum scabrum.Taste / Smell: Disappointing. Must be cooked before consumption.
Boletus / Leccinum scabrum.Other Facts: There have been reports from America that some people react badly to Leccinums but these are not confirmed, however it has been suggested that you cook all Leccinums before consumption.

Boletus / Leccinum versipelle.Description: A tasty member of the greater Bolete family. This mushroom can sometimes also be known as theBoletus testaceoscaberorBoletus rufescens.
Boletus / Leccinum versipelle.Synonyms: Boletus versipellis, Boletus testaceoscaber, Boletus rufescens
